metadata.synopsis: Mizora goes to players camp whether or not Wyll keeps the pact.
metadata.how_to_trigger: - Meet Mizora with Wyll at 2; 46; 253;- Agree to keep the pact; - Go to player camp;

197.speaker: Mizora
197.text: Such language. Didn't your father teach you any manners?

388.speaker: Player
388.text: You killed Wyll's father right in front of him. Why don't you go back to the Hells, where you belong?

229.speaker: Mizora
229.text: You've got it all wrong, bug. Wyll killed his father. His wish, my command.

362.speaker: Mizora
362.text: But at least you got to pay your last respects.

407.speaker: Player
407.text: Disgusting creature. You killed Ravengard right in front of me.

414.speaker: Player
414.text: A deal's a deal. But I didn't know I'd have to watch Ravengard die.

265.speaker: Mizora
265.text: And here I thought you'd be grateful for the final good-bye.

270.speaker: Mizora
270.text: I stayed to true to the bargain. Isn't it a relief to know I'm always good for my word?

386.speaker: Player
386.text: That was a nasty display at the Iron Throne. I bet you enjoyed every moment.

370.speaker: Mizora
370.text: Far from it. It wrecked me to see Wyll's father come to such a cruel end.

64.speaker: Narrator
64.text: *Mizora eyes you silently. She wants to speak with Wyll.*

72.speaker: Mizora
72.text: 'Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard.' What a thrill! Imagine the statues they'll build, the songs that they'll sing!

312.speaker: Mizora
312.text: So what's our first order of business, sir duke?

339.speaker: Wyll
339.text: 'Our' order of business? You need to stay out of Baldur's Gate's affairs.

16.speaker: Mizora
16.text: Is it possible? Could the courageous Wyll Ravengard be this heartbreakingly naive?

97.speaker: Mizora
97.text: Clause One, Section One: 'Soul-bearer pledges his soul to half-fiend Mizora and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.'

66.speaker: Mizora
66.text: Don't worry, I won't keep too tight a leash. He scratches my horns, and I'll scratch his.

413.speaker: Mizora
413.text: You and me, duke and advisor. Baldur's Gate's outlook is radiant indeed.

148.speaker: Mizora
148.text: So what's your first order of business, sir duke?

189.speaker: Wyll
189.text: The elder brain is first on the list. Everything else will need to wait.

169.speaker: Mizora
169.text: Yes. To kill the Absolute, to free the infected, to end the illithid Grand Design. Could there be a more heroic journey?

195.speaker: Mizora
195.text: Well, apart from the whole 'devil pulling the strings' aspect, of course.

435.speaker: Mizora
435.text: But what about the next battle, and the next? How mighty will the stalwart Blade be, without warlock powers to help him?

159.speaker: Mizora
159.text: Tell me you haven't forgotten. Once the Absolute is no more, so is my aid.

333.speaker: Mizora
333.text: Well - perhaps I might stop by once a tenday, see how the pup's getting along. A bit of infernal altruism, if you will.

69.speaker: Mizora
69.text: Ah, the thrill of the unknown! I can't wait to see what's in store for Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke.

186.speaker: Wyll
186.text: You know exactly what's on my mind.

423.speaker: Player
423.text: Cordula Eltan accosted us in the Lower City. What in the hells did you tell her?

112.speaker: Player
112.text: Florrick accosted us in the Lower City. What in the hells did you tell her?

306.speaker: Mizora
306.text: Why, only the truth - that you bear the blame for the duke's untimely demise.

421.speaker: Mizora
421.text: Such a loyal servant of the city, so eager to hear of your exploits. Tell me, darling - how is she?

163.speaker: Player
163.text: Hello, Mizora. Or should I say 'Lady Mizora'?

58.speaker: Mizora
58.text: So you talked to Cordula? Such an elegant woman - so protective of the city, so eager to hear of your exploits.

315.speaker: Mizora
315.text: Tell me, darling - how is she?

358.speaker: Player
358.text: She's gone for good, thanks to your meddling.

111.speaker: Mizora
111.text: What a shame. Ravengard, Eltan - Baldur's Gate has lost its brightest stars.

190.speaker: Mizora
190.text: Someone will need to step up and lead in their absence, a man with the spirit of a dragon.

427.speaker: Mizora
427.text: What a shame. Ravengard, Florrick - Baldur's Gate has lost its brightest stars.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: Alive, no thanks to you. I convinced her to stand down.

156.speaker: Mizora
156.text: What a relief. It would be a shame if she'd struck down the one and only Blade.

89.speaker: Mizora
89.text: Alas, she misses the fallen duke. Someone will need to step up in his absence, a man with the spirit of a dragon.

334.speaker: Player
334.text: How dare you interfere? I am not to blame for Ravengard's death!

389.speaker: Player
389.text: As if you care. Is this the kind of 'entertainment' you wanted?

25.speaker: Mizora
25.text: Entertainment? I'd be a cheeky devil indeed to make such diabolical merry!

17.speaker: Mizora
17.text: Glower all you want - I was merely laying the path to Wyll's success.

138.speaker: Mizora
138.text: With the duke and his closest confidantes gone, someone will need to step up in their absence. A man with the spirit of a dragon.

38.speaker: Mizora
38.text: With the duke gone, someone will need to step up in his absence. A man with the spirit of a dragon.

420.speaker: Mizora
420.text: So you talked to Florrick? The city's most loyal servant. Positively outraged to hear how Wyll failed his father.

391.speaker: Player
391.text: Blasted devil. If you're trying to get me killed, you almost succeeded.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: I don't get it. If Wyll isn't your warlock, why stick around and give him power?

406.speaker: Mizora
406.text: Just because you're not my pet doesn't mean you're not useful.

371.speaker: Mizora
371.text: The Absolutists worked a number on me at Moonrise. And you're the best hope I've got at payback.

288.speaker: Mizora
288.text: No one crosses the Hells' children without getting scorched.

255.speaker: Player
255.text: What do you have planned for Wyll now that the pact is eternally sealed?

143.speaker: Mizora
143.text: Focus on the elder brain. I'd hate to clog that infected head of yours with needless details.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: I'm sure my infected head has room for a hint, at least.

192.speaker: Mizora
192.text: *Sigh.* You're a gifted hunter, pup. And Zariel's made her share of enemies in and out of the Hells.

7.speaker: Mizora
7.text: Devils, demons, deserters. They're a great burden on the Lord of the First.

304.speaker: Mizora
304.text: Clause G, Section Nine: 'Targets shall be limited to the infernal, the demonic, the heartless, and the soulless.'

375.speaker: Mizora
375.text: The clause holds, Wyll. Don't tug on my leash, and you'll be stalking only the wickedest prey.

168.speaker: Mizora
168.text: *Sigh.* Wyll's a gifted hunter. And Zariel's made her share of enemies in and out of the Hells.

98.speaker: Mizora
98.text: The clause still holds. As long as Wyll doesn't tug on my leash, he'll be stalking only the wickedest prey.

135.speaker: Mizora
135.text: Now now, you know what they say about curiosity and cats.

80.speaker: Mizora
80.text: They do have cats from where you come from, don't they? Hm.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: I'd do anything for Wyll. That includes not murdering you on the spot.

217.speaker: Mizora
217.text: Oh, don't let him spoil our fun. Come at me, sister. See what happens.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: You've left Karlach alone. Didn't you want her dead? What changed?

26.speaker: Mizora
26.text: Oh, you are an inquisitive one.

273.speaker: Mizora
273.text: I'd think you'd figured by now - Zariel found a new use for an old battleaxe.

37.speaker: Mizora
37.text: The Dead Three and that bulging brain of theirs are a threat to more than this trifling city, you know.

92.speaker: Mizora
92.text: Savour her company. Who's to say when Zariel might change her mind?

419.speaker: Mizora
419.text: My mistress can be so capricious.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: What can you tell me about the Hells?

463.speaker: Mizora
463.text: The Nine Hells of Baator. Each its own domain, each with its own archdevil to rule it.

175.speaker: Mizora
175.text: I call the first hell my home. Avernus, my mistress Zariel's realm - a torrid battleground split by the bloody waters of the Styx.

93.speaker: Mizora
93.text: How I adore it. The delicious agony of it all.

246.speaker: Mizora
246.text: The other eight, well, they are pleasures unto themselves. Perhaps I'll show you myself - if I deem you worthy.

90.speaker: Mizora
90.text: The other eight, well, they are pleasures unto themselves. I pity those who can never know them.

301.speaker: Player
301.text: You never told me how the Absolutists captured you.

82.speaker: Mizora
82.text: If you must know, I was scouting the cultists on behalf of Zariel. But those cursed shadows were thick enough to fell even a half-fiend.

215.speaker: Mizora
215.text: I woke in that damned pod. It kept my body sealed and my most powerful magic silenced.

434.speaker: Mizora
434.text: But a brave, kind, benevolent soul set me free. Gallantry isn't dead after all.

338.speaker: Player
338.text: I want you out of here. Now.

118.speaker: Mizora
118.text: I'm afraid that's not an option. I'm quite stubborn, you see.

133.speaker: Mizora
133.text: Take a swing or a stab if you want, but I'll just slip away for a breather. One of the perks of being a half-devil, of course.

344.speaker: Mizora
344.text: Besides, if you did manage a killing blow, I wouldn't be the only victim.

141.speaker: Mizora
141.text: Young Wyll would be sucked into Avernus and take up arms in the Blood War.

198.speaker: Mizora
198.text: And I'm not done with him yet. Our future together looks real bright.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: If you're going to be staying, I need something in return.

262.speaker: Mizora
262.text: Why, I'm supplying Wyll with every scrap of his infernal power. I've paid my dues many times over.

110.speaker: Mizora
110.text: I tell you what. When the time comes to squish that big baddie of a brain, I'll lend you a hand.

79.speaker: Mizora
79.text: Like I said. I'm the giving type.

160.speaker: Mizora
160.text: Little Wyll's all grown up. I can't wait to see what trouble he gets into.

447.speaker: Player
447.text: Cut the shit, Mizora. How dare you force me to make such an impossible choice?

187.speaker: Mizora
187.text: All that time together, and you still find ways to surprise me.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: You forced Wyll to make an impossible choice.

46.speaker: Mizora
46.text: Impossible? My bargain was uncommonly reasonable.

247.speaker: Mizora
247.text: A single soul for the return of Baldur's Gate's most beloved duke. A real bargain, I should think.

71.speaker: Mizora
71.text: I never thought the legendary Blade of Frontiers would surrender his father for freedom.

242.speaker: Mizora
242.text: Not very valorous if you ask me. But what does a mean ol' devil like me know about heroes?

40.speaker: Player
40.text: I'm not a child. You need to start treating me with respect.

39.speaker: Mizora
39.text: Oh, you have found your bark! I beg your forgiveness for such undue impertinence.

125.speaker: Mizora
125.text: I promise you the same measure of respect you've shown your father.

55.speaker: Mizora
55.text: Oh, I almost forgot - you sold his life for your freedom. My mistake.

282.speaker: Player
282.text: Wyll's not a child. You need to start treating him with respect.

103.speaker: Mizora
103.text: I beg your forgiveness for such undue impertinence.

119.speaker: Mizora
119.text: From now on, I promise him the same measure of respect he's shown his father.

62.speaker: Mizora
62.text: Oh, I almost forgot - Wyll sold his father's life for his freedom. My mistake.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: I... sacrificed my own father to save myself. What kind of monster have I become?

61.speaker: Mizora
61.text: Don't be so hard on yourself. I'm sure you carefully weighed the pros and cons.

153.speaker: Mizora
153.text: Pro: freedom. No more pact, no more hellbound soul. Con: killing off your own father, Baldur's Gate's most beloved duke, and forever altering the city's future.

259.speaker: Mizora
259.text: Oh! Well, maybe 'monster' isn't so far off.

271.speaker: Player
271.text: I can't believe Wyll actually sacrificed his father to save himself.

53.speaker: Mizora
53.text: Don't be so hard on him. I'm sure he carefully weighed the pros and cons.

443.speaker: Mizora
443.text: Pro: freedom. No more pact, no more hellbound soul. Con: killing off his own father, Baldur's Gate's most beloved duke, and forever altering the city's future.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: That's it then. My father is dead.

100.speaker: Mizora
100.text: Well, not exactly. But it's only a matter of time.

390.speaker: Mizora
390.text: Come now, don't be hard on yourself. I'm sure you carefully weighed the pros and cons.

234.speaker: Mizora
234.text: I would have done the same thing in your shoes. But what do I know about heroes?

108.speaker: Player
108.text: That's it, then. Duke Ravengard's dead.

324.speaker: Mizora
324.text: Don't be too hard on Wyll. I'm sure he carefully weighed the pros and cons.

144.speaker: Mizora
144.text: I would have done the same thing in his shoes. But what do I know about heroes?

180.speaker: Mizora
180.text: Why the stunned face? You look like you've seen a devil.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: Cut the shit, Mizora. How dare you force me to make such an impossible choice?

104.speaker: Player
104.text: You forced Wyll to make an impossible choice.

305.speaker: Mizora
305.text: To wit: go to Gortash's secret prison, and I'll help you spring Wyll's daddy free.

346.speaker: Player
346.text: Wyll sacrificed his soul for his father. You better fulfil your end of the bargain.

309.speaker: Mizora
309.text: I am a woman of my word. Go to the Iron Throne, and I'll help you spring Wyll's daddy free.

287.speaker: Mizora
287.text: I am a woman of my word. Go to Gortash's secret prison, and I'll help you spring Wyll's daddy free.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: I sold you my soul for my father. You better fulfil your end of the bargain.

85.speaker: Mizora
85.text: I am a woman of my word. Go to Gortash's secret prison, and I'll help you spring your daddy free.

323.speaker: Mizora
323.text: Of course, you could always leave him to rot.

30.speaker: Mizora
30.text: But that would make Wyll's sacrifice worthless. And I know you wouldn't want that.

457.speaker: Player
457.text: You're as cunning as a fox. It's a delight to see you in action.

157.speaker: Player
157.text: I should be angry with you. But I'm just in awe of your cunning.

286.speaker: Player
286.text: I have. But even the lowliest devils honour their agreements, don't they?

207.speaker: Mizora
207.text: 'Grand Duke Wyll Ravengard.' What a thrill! Imagine the statues they'll build, the songs that they'll sing!

452.speaker: Mizora
452.text: So what's our first order of business, sir duke?

14.speaker: Player
14.text: The elder brain is first on the list. Everything else will need to wait.

430.speaker: Mizora
430.text: Well - perhaps I might stop by once a tenday, see how the pup's getting along. A bit of infernal altruism, if you will.

241.speaker: Mizora
241.text: Ah, the thrill of the unknown! I can't wait to see what's in store for Baldur's Gate's newest Grand Duke.

274.speaker: Player
274.text: 'Our' order of business? You need to stay out of Baldur's Gate's affairs.

128.speaker: Mizora
128.text: Is it possible? Could the courageous Wyll Ravengard be this heartbreakingly naive?

295.speaker: Mizora
295.text: Clause One, Section One: 'Soul-bearer pledges his soul to half-fiend Mizora and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.'

19.speaker: Mizora
19.text: You and me, duke and advisor. Baldur's Gate's outlook is radiant indeed.

412.speaker: Mizora
412.text: Oh, how the people will applaud their courageous Grand Duke!

222.speaker: Mizora
222.text: Do you, now? Mistress Zariel will be pleased to hear it.

348.speaker: Player
348.text: You need to keep out of Baldur's Gate's business, Mizora.

176.speaker: Mizora
176.text: You're stuck with me for good.

4.speaker: Mizora
4.text: But do tell me you haven't forgotten. Once the Absolute is no more, so is my aid.

380.speaker: Player
380.text: I will destroy Orin the Red.

395.speaker: Player
395.text: I do like when you call me that. Say it again.

313.speaker: Mizora
313.text: 'Sir duke?' Marvellous - you are already giddy with power and possibility.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: I find a way to kill my former patron.

200.speaker: Mizora
200.context: NodeContext: Absolutely amused that Wyll/player thinks they can kill her

179.speaker: Mizora
179.text: Once the Absolute is no more, so is my aid. Poof - there go your warlock powers.

11.speaker: Mizora
11.text: But I do enjoy a game of cat and mouse. Let the Grand Duke give chase. I might even let him catch me.

67.speaker: Mizora
67.text: Let's see how well he suffers the burn.

70.speaker: Mizora
70.text: So what's your first order of business, sir duke?

249.speaker: Mizora
249.text: All that trouble I went to. The planning, the anticipation -

327.speaker: Mizora
327.text: - and then you kill the poor duke yourself. I'm nothing if not impressed.

290.speaker: Player
290.text: It was an accident. I didn't mean to do it, I swear.

20.speaker: Mizora
20.text: You don't owe me an explanation, pet. He was as good as dead before you ever set foot in the Iron Throne. That was the deal, after all.

245.speaker: Mizora
245.text: I just didn't expect you'd take it so literally.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: A terrible, violent display. And I bet you enjoyed every moment.

140.speaker: Mizora
140.text: Such is the lure of power, I suppose. With your father gone, the people will look to his heir for direction.

63.speaker: Mizora
63.text: And I bet you're full of ideas.

212.speaker: Player
212.text: I wanted to handle it myself. He had it coming.

436.speaker: Mizora
436.text: Oh, I do love when you get nasty. The Blade's always had an edge.

251.speaker: Mizora
251.context: NodeContext: Sarcastic of course. Extra sarcastic when referring to Karlach directly

263.speaker: Mizora
263.text: I bet you're pleased with yourself. Saving Ravengard and making a fool out of me in a single swoop.

33.speaker: Mizora
33.text: Go on, do your gloating. You earned it.

173.speaker: Wyll
173.text: Damn I right I did. My father is safe and my chains are broken!

465.speaker: Player
465.text: I certainly did. Wyll's father is safe, and Wyll's free of you at last.

437.speaker: Mizora
437.text: I've never seen you so giddy, Karlach. Go on, celebrate your fortunes. But remember that they are lost as quickly as they are gained.

201.speaker: Player
201.text: Damn I right I did. My father is safe and my chains are broken!

42.speaker: Mizora
42.text: I've never seen you so giddy, Wyll. Go on, celebrate your fortunes. But remember that they are lost as quickly as they are gained.

455.speaker: Mizora
455.text: For now, you've tipped the scales in your favour. But all it takes is a whisper for me to tip them back.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: I know you will come for him. Try it, and I'll save him again - and kill you while I'm at it.

151.speaker: Mizora
151.text: Clause A, Section Two: 'Should soul-holder choose to abandon his patron, he is freed from his duty. His father, Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard, will be thus fated to die by an enemy's hand.'

268.speaker: Mizora
268.text: A sealed pact is mightier than even Asmodeus' ruby rod. Do you think by merely saving a duke that you were ripping it through?

10.speaker: Mizora
10.text: You're such a witless little thing. Laugh in the face of the Archduchess Zariel, and she only laughs back.

398.speaker: Mizora
398.text: By all means, struggle and seethe when I come for Zariel's prize. Play the hero, put up a fight.

252.speaker: Mizora
252.text: But don't forget who signed away his own father's life when Ravengard's finally bled.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: What did you mean, about tipping the scales in your favour?

376.speaker: Mizora
376.text: Why look for hidden meaning when the words are laid so bare?

356.speaker: Mizora
356.text: Besides, now is a time of celebration. I am sure you and Duke Ravengard have plenty to talk about.

95.speaker: Mizora
95.text: Ravengard will fall. I will strike when the Duke has the most to lose - and I have the most to gain.

325.speaker: Mizora
325.text: Now now, have some manners. It's not polite to dig around in a lady's mind without her permission.

194.speaker: Player
194.text: It's a trick, it's got to be. A bargain's a bargain, right?

107.speaker: Mizora
107.text: Indeed - a bargain's a bargain. And the man who skirts a sworn pact is living on borrowed time.

343.speaker: Player
343.text: I'm just relieved that Grand Duke Ravengard is all right.

225.speaker: Player
225.text: You're such a loser, Mizora. You broke a contract and got nothing out of it. Ha!

216.speaker: Mizora
216.text: Yes, celebrate your fortunes. But remember that they are lost as quickly as they are gained.

277.speaker: Mizora
277.text: I do so love when someone does the work and I get all the credit.

340.speaker: Mizora
340.text: To think I went through all that trouble, only for you to land the final blow.

361.speaker: Player
361.text: It was an accident. I didn't mean to do it, I swear.

31.speaker: Mizora
31.text: You don't owe me an explanation. Like most other mortals, Ravengard was always bound for the grave.

88.speaker: Mizora
88.text: I just never expected you'd speed up the process.

233.speaker: Mizora
233.text: Well - at least you got to pay your last respects...

74.speaker: Mizora
74.text: ...and Ravengard died knowing the face of his killer.

319.speaker: Player
319.text: A terrible, violent display. You must be positively ecstatic over it.

459.speaker: Mizora
459.text: Far from it. I'm positively wrecked to see my poor Wyll orphaned like this.

101.speaker: Player
101.text: I wanted to handle it myself. He had it coming.

329.speaker: Mizora
329.text: Oh, I do love when you lot get nasty. I've always appreciated your sharp edges.

283.speaker: Mizora
283.text: I've had my eye on you.

106.speaker: Mizora
106.text: Since I made you a devil, the heat of Avernus burns ever hotter in you.

235.speaker: Mizora
235.text: You sizzle like brimstone, glow like hot iron -

445.speaker: Mizora
445.text: - and seethe like the River Styx. But there's something missing, isn't there?

335.speaker: Mizora
335.text: You're hungry for pleasures beyond this plane. Something more satisfying than mortal flesh, blood, and bone.

408.speaker: Player
408.text: If you've come to make another bargain with me, I've had my fill.

280.speaker: Mizora
280.text: Oh, but do hear me out - you want what I have to offer.

417.speaker: Player
417.text: I'm quite content, actually. Whatever you're offering, I'm not interested.

396.speaker: Player
396.text: Sounds delicious. What are you suggesting?

166.speaker: Player
166.text: I have no idea what you're on about.

429.speaker: Mizora
429.text: I'm talking of the mundanity of a life ignorant to the thrills of the Nine Hells.

96.speaker: Mizora
96.text: Yes. You're curious - your eyes are lit like raging stars. You want what only I can give you.

425.speaker: Mizora
425.text: The ecstasy of agony. The pain of the damned, distilled into pure bliss - beyond every climax you've known. The little death, writ large.

350.speaker: Mizora
350.text: Smile, and I'll come to you when you put your head down to rest. I will sate your most forbidden lusts.

416.speaker: Mizora
416.text: Or don't, and know the eternal ache of the unknown and the unanswered.

209.speaker: Player
209.text: I'm not sure. I'm involved with someone else.

328.speaker: Mizora
328.text: Then we'll keep it our little secret, hand to beating heart.

378.speaker: Player
378.text: What's the catch? What are you getting out of this visit?

354.speaker: Mizora
354.text: The same thrills I offer you. Some experiences are better when... shared.

278.speaker: Player
278.text: Smile the rictus grin of the damned.

131.speaker: Mizora
131.text: Oh, sister. I'm going to make this very worth your while.

404.speaker: Mizora
404.text: Trust me, I shan't be making that mistake again. Ta-ta!

116.speaker: Player
116.text: Words of temptation - the kind used by a patron seeking a pact.

409.speaker: Mizora
409.text: I am positively full-up on warlocks - and you are already claimed. What I offer is free for your taking.

123.speaker: Mizora
123.text: I know you want me, Karlach. You don't want to want me, of course. Which makes the longing all the more agonising.

458.speaker: Mizora
458.text: The fire of Avernus courses through you. And you know only I can bear it.

130.speaker: Mizora
130.text: You've been an ardent hellhound and hunter, Wyll - ever so eager to please. But I've seen something new:

382.speaker: Mizora
382.text: You crave elations unknown on this mortal plane. Something more satisfying than flesh, blood, and bone.

451.speaker: Mizora
451.text: You've been my private hellhound and hunter, Wyll - ever so eager. But I've seen something new:

211.speaker: Mizora
211.text: Hot as brimstone, jagged as lightning -

393.speaker: Mizora
393.text: - and sharp as Vlaakith's own silver blade. But there's something missing, isn't there?

385.speaker: Mizora
385.text: - and dark as the newest moon. But there's something missing, isn't there?

50.speaker: Mizora
50.text: - and radiant with Her Ladyship Zariel's blessings.

426.speaker: Mizora
426.text: - and seething like the River Styx. But there's something missing, isn't there?

291.speaker: Mizora
291.text: Such a touching reunion. It's enough to bring a tear to my eye.
291.context: NodeContext: Without a touch of actual teariness, of course.

154.speaker: Player
154.text: Cut the shit, Mizora. How dare you force me to make such an impossible choice?

449.speaker: Mizora
449.text: You dug your own hole, pup. I merely supplied the claws.

351.speaker: Player
351.text: You forced Wyll to make an impossible choice.

210.speaker: Mizora
210.text: The pup dug his own hole, darling. I merely supplied the claws.

372.speaker: Mizora
372.text: I've always been the giving type, after all.

392.speaker: Player
392.text: I'm glad to see Ravengard's safe. A shame Wyll had to sacrifice his eternal soul for him.

152.speaker: Mizora
152.text: Is it a shame, though? Is a single soul not worth the return of Baldur's Gate's most beloved duke?

310.speaker: Mizora
310.text: Imagine the battles he's still to lead once you've flattened the Absolute.

162.speaker: Mizora
162.text: Goodness me. For all that, a lone soul is a bargain.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I am glad my father's safe. But I won't thank you for it.

364.speaker: Mizora
364.text: Your father's dignified bearing and seething annoyance are thanks enough.

401.speaker: Mizora
401.text: Look at him. Staunch as an iron-cast statue, proud as a lion after the hunt.

54.speaker: Mizora
54.text: All that, for the measly cost of one soul. A real bargain, don't you think?

359.speaker: Player
359.text: You're as cunning as a fox. It's a delight to see you in action.

165.speaker: Mizora
165.text: Cunning, am I? Ah, you see me as a schemer, an exploiter. You've pegged me wrong, little bug.

57.speaker: Mizora
57.text: I am a benefactress. And I have an eye for a good cause. Wyll needed help, so I indulged him.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: I should be angry with you. But I'm just in awe of your cunning.

284.speaker: Mizora
284.text: I am a benefactress. And I have an eye for a good cause. You needed help, so I indulged you.

298.speaker: Mizora
298.text: What torment it must have been, to see the duke's corpse rotting in the Iron Throne.

297.speaker: Narrator
297.text: *Mizora sounds entirely too pleased with herself. She's keeping something from you.*

223.speaker: Player
223.text: You're hiding something. Spit it out, Mizora - you know you want to.

60.speaker: Mizora
60.text: Oh, I was just thinking of Wyll's father, the Grand Duke.

139.speaker: Mizora
139.text: The Dead Three had such big plans for him. Seems someone else had even bigger ones.

178.speaker: Mizora
178.text: Someone who needed a bargaining chip. Whoever could that be?
178.context: NodeContext: Particularly sarcastic at the end, smiling wide.

256.speaker: Wyll
256.text: It was you. You killed my father.

300.speaker: Mizora
300.text: Your words, not mine, pup. Besides, he's looking much better now, wouldn't you say?

454.speaker: Wyll
454.text: You are such a piece of shit, Mizora.
454.context: NodeContext: Simmering in anger towards Mizora

400.speaker: Mizora
400.text: Leave the obscenities to Karlach - coming from you, they sound positively unseemly.

120.speaker: Mizora
120.text: Goodness. I hardly expect such obscenity from the heroic Blade of Frontiers.

326.speaker: Mizora
326.text: Your words, not mine, pup. Besides, you could have undone it all in a snap.

347.speaker: Mizora
347.text: Paranoia doesn't become you, my dear.

314.speaker: Mizora
314.context: InternalNodeContext: Note - there are no lines inside the nested dialog, an AD plays instead, overriding it

424.speaker: Mizora
424.text: Still the Blade of Frontiers, is he? Never let it be said Wyll isn't consistent.

456.speaker: Mizora
456.text: It was good for me. Was it good for you?

374.speaker: Player
374.text: I take my pleasures wherever I please. Zariel would hate that, wouldn't she?

363.speaker: Mizora
363.text: Now, now, let's not bring Mummy into this. This is between us girls, isn't it?

49.speaker: Mizora
49.text: All that anger in you, Karlach - that pent-up fury and desire. It felt good to unleash them on the one person who could possible understand, didn't it?

285.speaker: Player
285.text: Godsdamn you, Mizora. Admit it: You were trying to cause trouble.

461.speaker: Mizora
461.text: Oh dear - the pangs of remorse. Is it our night you regret, or the fact we were caught?

345.speaker: Mizora
345.text: Judging by the zeal with which you tore into my flesh, I think it's the latter.

384.speaker: Mizora
384.text: I got what I wanted. So did you.

105.speaker: Mizora
105.text: I thought as much. You moaned like a dragon thrice-struck with a broadsword.

102.speaker: Mizora
102.text: You turned the pain of the damned into impossible pleasure.

28.speaker: Mizora
28.text: Your moans of ecstasy told me otherwise.

267.speaker: Mizora
267.text: But I understand. You have appearances to keep up, charades to play.

444.speaker: Mizora
444.text: But I know the truth, I see the change. You turned the pain of the damned into impossible pleasure.

279.speaker: Player
279.text: Our night together was a big mistake.

337.speaker: Mizora
337.text: Was it? You screamed like a banshee in a bathhouse when you climaxed.

466.speaker: Mizora
466.text: The Blade of Avernus. How marvellous - it rolls right off the tongue.

213.speaker: Mizora
213.text: Tell me, pet: who's our first target?

238.speaker: Mizora
238.text: Tell me, pet: who's your first target?

293.speaker: Player
293.text: The elder brain is first on the list. Everything else will need to wait.

336.speaker: Mizora
336.text: Yes. To kill the Absolute, to free the infected, to end the illithid Grand Design. Could there be a more heroic journey?

230.speaker: Mizora
230.text: But what about the next battle, and the next? How mighty will the stalwart Blade be, without warlock powers to help him?

214.speaker: Mizora
214.text: Well, apart from the whole 'devil pulling the strings' aspect, of course.

43.speaker: Mizora
43.text: Don't worry, I won't keep too tight a leash. He scratches my horns, and I'll scratch his.

6.speaker: Mizora
6.text: The pup can roam where he wants, as long he gives me no reason to tighten the leash.

422.speaker: Mizora
422.text: The terrible tyrant himself. Strike him down, bug - let freedom's bells ring. The brain won't be too far beyond.

5.speaker: Mizora
5.text: Oh, how the people will applaud their courageous hero.

77.speaker: Mizora
77.text: Well - if they're not revolted by those hideous horns.

352.speaker: Mizora
352.text: The mad assassin herself. Strike her down, bug - let her syndicate fall. The brain won't be too far beyond.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: There are plenty of cultists and monsters to go around. Take your pick.

330.speaker: Player
330.text: I'm sure he'll find plenty of prey in the wilds of the Sword Coast.

2.speaker: Mizora
2.text: The legend lives! Oh, how the people will applaud their courageous hero.

226.speaker: Mizora
226.text: I'll keep the whole 'devil pulling his strings' hush-hush, I promise.

36.speaker: Player
36.text: Lead him to the Hells. I'm sure he'll find plenty of quarry.

87.speaker: Mizora
87.text: He'll have his pick of the prey - within reason, of course.

199.speaker: Mizora
199.text: Demons are fair game. Zariel's enemies? Likewise. Devils threatening the Sword Coast? Fine by me.

3.speaker: Mizora
3.text: But if he messes with Zariel's faithful? He'll be turned to a lemure and answer to the Archduchess of Avernus.

94.speaker: Mizora
94.text: He can roam where he wants - until he gives me a reason to tighten the leash.

307.speaker: Mizora
307.text: But I do wonder - just how mighty will the stalwart Blade be, without warlock powers to help him?

442.speaker: Mizora
442.text: Tell me you haven't forgotten. Once the Absolute is no more, so is my aid.

438.speaker: Mizora
438.text: Well, perhaps I might pay a visit once he's settled, offer some advice. A bit of infernal altruism, if you will.

460.speaker: Mizora
460.text: Ah, the thrill of the unknown. I can't wait to see how this epic plays out.

433.speaker: Player
433.text: Zariel would be a good start.

368.speaker: Mizora
368.text: Funny girl. If Wyll so much as touches a faithful of Zariel - never mind Her Ladyship - he'll be turned into a lemure and left to rot in the deepest pit of Avernus.

32.speaker: Mizora
32.text: If you ask me, that's where our Lady should've left you long ago.

360.speaker: Mizora
360.text: I'd like to see him try. Poor kitten's utterly powerless without my help.

224.speaker: Mizora
224.text: Tell me, little bug: who should Wyll's first target be?
